questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of generalized fatigue and dark urine for 1 week. Four weeks ago, she was treated with topical mupirocin for a skin infection. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable and she takes no routine medications. Her 5-year-old brother has steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 132/89 mm Hg. Examination shows periorbital and 1+ pretibial edema bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.9 g/dL


Leukocyte count
7200/mm3



Platelet count
230,000/mm3



Serum



 Urea nitrogen
32 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.8 mg/dL


Urine



 Blood
2+


 Protein
2+


 Glucose
negative


 RBC
12–14/hpf with dysmorphic features


 RBC casts

numerous


Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

choices.text: Abnormal deposits of insoluble protein fibers

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis is caused by the deposition of immune complexes composed of IgG and C3 complement that contain the streptococcal antigen within the glomerular basement membrane. The deposition of immune complexes activates complement, additional immune mediators, and leads to local inflammation. This immune response damages the glomeruli and results in nephritic syndrome. Laboratory tests commonly also show decreased C3 complement levels due to activation of the alternative complement pathway.

The condition is typically self-limiting; treatment is supportive and focuses on complications of volume overload. Recovery of kidney function usually occurs within 6–8 weeks. While 90% of pediatric cases recover completely, approximately 50% of adult patients retain persistently reduced renal function.
Image Description:

Immunofluorescence photomicrograph of a renal biopsy specimen (very high magnification)

Subepithelial deposits of C3 are seen distributed within the capillary loops. The deposits are visible as bright green fluorescence in an irregular granular pattern.

This finding is typical of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Reactive amyloidosis (AA-amyloidosis) is caused by the deposition of amyloid-associated protein in various organs, including the kidneys. Patients with renal involvement present with nephrotic syndrome, not with nephritic syndrome as seen in this patient. Patients may also present with type II renal tubular acidosis or nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Reactive amyloidosis occurs secondarily to chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., inflammatory bowel disease, systemic lupus erythematosus, vasculitis) or chronic infections (e.g., tuberculosis, bronchiectasis), none of which are evident in this patient's history.

C) INCORRECT:

Goodpasture syndrome is caused by autoantibodies against type IV collagen in the renal and pulmonary capillary basement membrane. While Goodpasture syndrome may manifest with nephritis and can be triggered by infections, it often causes both renal and pulmonary manifestations such as hemoptysis, cough, or dyspnea, which are not seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy is thought to be caused by an increased number of defective circulating IgA antibodies. While patients with IgA nephropathy may present with nephritic syndrome following an infection, symptoms usually begin within 2–5 days after the infection, not after 3 weeks. In addition, IgA nephropathy is more commonly seen in the 2nd or 3rd decade of life and is most closely associated with mucosal infections (i.e., upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infections).

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is caused by antinuclear antibodies and anti-dsDNA autoantibodies. Lupus nephritis is common in patients with SLE and is classically an immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis. While patients with lupus nephritis also present with nephritic syndrome, this patient lacks other systemic symptoms of SLE such as lesions of the skin (e.g., malar rash, discoid rash, oral ulcers), arthritis, and fever.

F) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of small-sized blood vessels causes small vessel vasculitis including granulomatosis with polyangiitis or Churg-Strauss syndrome. While small-vessel vasculitis can also manifest with nephritic syndrome, it typically affects multiple organ systems and not just the kidneys. Furthermore, it is not associated with skin infections as seen in this patient's history.
questions.hint: The presence of dark urine, hypertension, edema, and microscopic hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs is indicative of nephritic syndrome. This condition can occur within 3–4 weeks after infections with group A streptococci such as impetigo.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the physician because of dark urine and decreased urine output for 2 days. He had a skin infection that required antibiotic treatment 3 weeks ago but stopped the antibiotics early because the infection had resolved. His blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows periorbital edema bilaterally. A photomicrograph of a renal biopsy specimen is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A mutation in type IV collagen causes Alport syndrome, which manifests with features of glomerulonephritis (i.e., dark-colored urine due to hematuria, hypertension, and edema), which are seen in this patient. However, most symptomatic patients present in infancy or childhood and also have sensorineural hearing loss. Furthermore, a renal biopsy would show mesangial cell proliferation and sclerosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired glutathione regeneration is seen in patients with G6PD deficiency. Glutathione is an important antioxidant. A deficiency of it renders RBCs susceptible to oxidative stress (e.g., a recent infection), which results in episodic hemolytic anemia. Although it may manifest with dark urine (hemoglobinuria), concomitant renal dysfunction is not typically seen in G6PD deficiency. Furthermore, other typical features of G6PD deficiency, e.g., abdominal pain, back pain, jaundice, and splenomegaly, would also be expected in this patient.
Image Description:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate while reducing NADP to NADPH. NADPH is essential for converting oxidized glutathione back to its reduced form (GSH). The reduced glutathione is capable of neutralizing reactive oxygen species (e.g., hydrogen peroxide) and free radicals, thereby protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

In G6PD deficiency, glutathione cannot be reduced and erythrocytes become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in damage to the erythrocyte membrane, and thus intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

C) INCORRECT:

Mesangial IgA deposits on renal biopsy are a characteristic finding in patients with IgA nephropathy. IgA nephropathy commonly manifests with features of nephritic syndrome (i.e., hematuria, edema, hypertension) in individuals in their 2nd to 3rd decade of life, which is consistent with this patient's age. However, it typically occurs immediately following or during a mucosal infection (e.g., upper respiratory tract and gastrointestinal infections), not several weeks after a skin infection. Additionally, most patients also have flank pain and a low-grade fever, which are absent in this case.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain)

A glomerulus surrounded by numerous tubules is visible in the center of each image. There is a proliferation of mesangial cells (examples marked by yellow circles) with extracellular matrix deposition within the glomeruli. In IgA nephropathy, these changes can range from focal segmental (examples indicated by black arrows) to diffuse (examples indicated by yellow arrow-heads).

This is the characteristic histopathologic appearance of IgA nephropathy.

Blue outlines: Glomerular capillaries

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated creatine phosphokinase is a marker of rhabdomyolysis, which can manifest with renal dysfunction and dark urine (due to myoglobinuria). Severe viral infections can cause myositis and rhabdomyolysis, but these features would not be expected following a localized skin infection. Renal biopsy is not required to diagnose rhabdomyolysis but, if performed, would show evidence of acute tubular necrosis (i.e., normal glomeruli and necrosed tubular epithelial cells).

E) INCORRECT:

Thrombocytopenia in a patient with recent-onset renal dysfunction is typically seen in hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). Although HUS can manifest with hematuria, edema, and hypertension, evidence of hemolytic anemia (i.e., pallor, icterus) and thrombocytopenia (i.e., mucocutaneous bleeding) would also be expected. In addition, renal dysfunction in HUS is typically preceded by a history of bloody diarrhea (not a skin infection) from infection with Shiga toxin-producing bacteria (e.g., EHEC, Shigella) and most commonly occurs in children rather than adults. Furthermore, a renal biopsy in HUS would show microthrombi in the glomerular capillaries.
Image Description:

Microscopic image of the kidney (van Gieson's stain)

Microthrombi from cell residues (yellow) and fibrin (bright red) in the glomerular capillaries.

F) CORRECT:

Elevated anti-DNase B titers indicate a recent infection by GAS. Infection with nephritogenic strains of GAS results in subepithelial immune complex deposition within the glomerular basement membrane (type III hypersensitivity reaction), which activates the complement system. This results in glomerular inflammation and nephritic syndrome, which is then known as poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Although PSGN is more common in young children and older adults, it can occur at any age. Adults are more likely to suffer from lasting kidney damage after PSGN, while the vast majority (> 90%) of children will fully recover.

Laboratory studies in this patient would also show a decreased C3 complement level due to increased complement consumption. ASO titers may also be elevated but may be falsely negative, especially after a GAS skin infection, as in this case.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of nephritic syndrome (i.e., oliguria, dark urine due to hematuria, periorbital edema, and hypertension) after a recent skin infection, most likely caused by group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (GAS). The image shows an enlarged hypercellular glomerulus with numerous inflammatory cells, which is characteristic of glomerulonephritis.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of generalized fatigue and dark urine for 4 days. Four weeks ago, she was treated with cephalexin for a skin infection. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) and blood pressure is 132/89 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 1+ pretibial edema bilaterally. Her serum creatinine is 1.7 mg/dL. Urine studies show:


Blood
2+


Protein
2+


RBC
12–14/hpf with dysmorphic features


RBC casts
numerous


Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis is a type III hypersensitivity reaction caused by the deposition of IgG immune complexes within the glomerular basement membrane, which leads to the activation and deposition of complement (mainly C3) and subsequent decrease in serum C3 due to consumption. This immune response results in damage to the glomeruli and manifests with nephritic syndrome, as seen in this patient. This condition is most commonly seen in children 1–3 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis or 1–6 weeks after streptococcal skin infection. Recovery of kidney function in children usually occurs spontaneously within 6–8 weeks. On light microscopy, PSGN manifests with enlarged and hypercellular glomeruli; on electron microscopy, it manifests with characteristic subepithelial immune complex humps.
Image Description:

Transmission electron micrograph (TEM) of renal tissue from a patient with non-HBV associated PIGN

A glomerular capillary containing a red blood cell (red overlay) and an epithelial foot process of a renal podocyte can be seen (green overlay). Multiple hump-shaped electron-dense deposits (arrows) are also apparent.

These subepithelial immune complex deposits may be present in PIGN.

Blue overlay: nucleus of endothelial cell

B) INCORRECT:

Reactive amyloidosis (AA-amyloidosis) is caused by the deposition of insoluble amyloid proteins in various organs, including the kidneys. Patients with renal involvement typically present with nephrotic syndrome, not with the nephritic syndrome seen here. Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by massive renal loss of protein (> 3.5 g/day) resulting in edema, hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, hypercoagulability (antithrombin III deficiency), and an increased risk of infection (loss of immunoglobulins). Reactive amyloidosis most commonly occurs secondary to chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., IBD, SLE, vasculitis) or chronic infections (e.g., tuberculosis, bronchiectasis), none of which are evident in this patient's history.

C) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy is thought to be caused by an increased number of defective circulating IgA antibodies. While patients with IgA nephropathy can present with nephritic syndrome following an infection, symptoms usually begin within 2–5 days after the infection, not after 3 weeks. In addition, IgA nephropathy is more commonly seen in the 2nd or 3rd decade of life and is most closely associated with mucosal infections (i.e., upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infections), rather than the skin infection seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Goodpasture syndrome is caused by autoantibodies against type IV collagen in the renal and pulmonary capillary basement membrane. While Goodpasture syndrome may manifest with nephritic syndrome and can be triggered by infections, it typically has both renal and pulmonary manifestations such as hemoptysis, cough, or dyspnea, which are not seen in this patient. Furthermore, it does not typically follow streptococcal disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Lupus nephritis is characterized by DNA-anti-DNA immune complex deposition in the glomeruli and can manifest as either nephrotic syndrome or nephritic syndrome. However, this patient's age and the absence of other systemic symptoms of SLE (e.g., malar rash, discoid rash, arthritis) make this unlikely.
questions.hint: The presence of dark urine, hypertension, edema, and microscopic hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs is indicative of nephritic syndrome. Given the history of recent skin infection, she most likely has post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis due to recent group A streptococcal infection.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of hematuria. Two weeks ago, she had a sore throat that resolved without treatment. Physical examination shows 1+ pitting edema of the lower legs and ankles. Urinalysis shows numerous RBCs and 3+ proteinuria. Her antistreptolysin O titer is elevated. Formation of which of the following is most likely involved in the underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Antigen-specific IgE binding to mast cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antigen-specific IgE binding to mast cells is part of the pathogenesis of type I hypersensitivity reactions such as anaphylaxis, in which antigen binding to surface IgE results in mast cell degranulation, releasing histamine and chemokines. The clinical manifestations of a type I hypersensitivity reaction are often seen in minutes, not weeks. Moreover, PSGN is not caused by a type I hypersensitivity reaction.

B) INCORRECT:

Tissue-specific autoantibodies are involved in the pathogenesis of type II hypersensitivity reactions. Healthy cells may be injured via several mechanisms, including antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity, complement-mediated inflammation, and antibody-mediated disruption of cell surface receptors. Although PSGN is an immunological phenomenon, it is not caused by a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

C) INCORRECT:

Presensitized CD4+ helper T-cells are involved in the pathogenesis of type IV hypersensitivity reactions such as allergic contact dermatitis. These T-cells bind to MHC class II on antigen-presenting cells via the T-cell receptor and release cytokines, causing inflammation and cellular injury. PSGN is not caused by a type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

D) CORRECT:

Antigen-antibody complexes (also known as immune complexes) are responsible for type III hypersensitivity reactions. Immune complexes activate the complement system, attracting neutrophils that cause endothelial damage. In PSGN, immune complexes composed of IgG and C3 complement that contain streptococcal antigens are deposited in the glomerulus.

E) INCORRECT:

CD8+ T-cells are involved in the pathogenesis of type IV hypersensitivity reactions such as graft versus host disease. These T-cells bind to MHC class I on somatic cells via the T-cell receptor and induce target cell death. PSGN is not caused by a type IV hypersensitivity reaction.
questions.hint: A presentation of hematuria and proteinuria (i.e., nephritic syndrome) with elevated antistreptolysin O titers in the setting of a recent sore throat indicates poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). The pathophysiology of PSGN involves a type III hypersensitivity reaction to streptococcal antigens.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl comes to the physician with her mother because of a 2-day history of passing “cola-colored“ urine. During the past week, her mother noticed episodes of facial swelling. The patient had a rash on her face about 4 weeks ago. A renal biopsy after immunofluorescence is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is an acute glomerular inflammation caused by the deposition of immune complexes along the glomerular basement membrane and mesangium in response to infection with nephritogenic strains of group A streptococci (GAS). PSGN classically occurs in children 1–6 weeks after infection (e.g., impetigo) and manifests with periorbital (or generalized) edema and gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine), both of which are seen in this patient. In addition, PSGN can also manifest with hypertension, azotemia, and proteinuria. Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 create a characteristic “lumpy-bumpy” appearance on immunofluorescence of a renal biopsy specimen.
Image Description:

Immunofluorescence photomicrograph of a renal biopsy specimen (very high magnification)

Subepithelial deposits of C3 are seen distributed within the capillary loops. The deposits are visible as bright green fluorescence in an irregular granular pattern.

This finding is typical of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Alport syndrome, a hereditary type of glomerulonephritis caused by a mutation in type IV collagen, can manifest with gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) and facial edema, as seen in this patient. However, this condition is most commonly inherited in an X-linked pattern, with females rarely being affected. Moreover, Alport syndrome is characterized by additional features, such as sensorineural deafness and multiple eye disorders (e.g., lens dislocation), as well as a positive family history of kidney failure and hearing loss, none of which is present here. In addition, immunofluorescence of a renal biopsy specimen would show an absence of type IV collagen rather than the granular immune complex deposition seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in black and Hispanic populations as well as the most common cause of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome in children. FSGS can be primary (i.e., idiopathic), secondary (e.g., associated with heroin use, HIV or HBV infection, sickle cell disease), or genetic. This patient has had multiple episodes of facial edema, which is consistent with this diagnosis; however, gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) would be an unlikely finding in FSGS. In addition, immunofluorescence in FSGS is typically unremarkable but may show IgM and C3 deposition within sclerotic lesions. It would not show the diffuse granular appearance seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in childhood, which can manifest with facial edema, as seen in this patient. MCD is thought to result from injury to podocytes and is typically triggered by a recent infection or immunization in an otherwise healthy child. However, the presence of gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) is inconsistent with this diagnosis. In addition, immunofluorescence of a renal biopsy specimen would show normal-appearing glomeruli rather than the granular deposition seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy is a type of glomerulonephritis caused by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in the mesangium. It is most common in children and young adults and can manifest with gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) and facial edema, which are seen in this patient. Immunofluorescence of a renal biopsy specimen typically shows granular deposition in the mesangium (mostly IgA). However, hematuria due to IgA nephropathy usually occurs concurrently with nonspecific respiratory, or less commonly, gastrointestinal or urinary tract infections. This patient instead presents in the postinfectious period, 4 weeks after having a rash, suggesting another diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Membranous nephropathy (MN) is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in white adults. Renal biopsy specimens in patients with MN typically show immune complex deposits (mostly IgG and C3) on immunofluorescence, which are seen here. MN rarely manifests in childhood; however, when children are affected, the most common associations include hepatitis B infection and autoimmune or thyroid disease, none of which is present in this patient. Although MN can manifest with facial edema, gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) would be an unlikely finding. Moreover, this patient's recent rash suggests another diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), a rare glomerular disease that most commonly appears in childhood and early adulthood, often manifests with both nephritic and nephrotic syndrome. Based on immunofluorescence examination, there are two major types of MPGN. Immunoglobulin-mediated MPGN (type I), which is often secondary to hepatitis B or hepatitis C infection, typically involves granular deposition along the glomerular basement membrane and mesangium, as seen in this patient's biopsy. Immunofluorescence microscopy of complement-mediated MPGN (type II) typically shows C3 deposition in the glomerular capillary wall, but no granular pattern. Although both types of MPGN can manifest with gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) and facial edema, the patient's recent rash suggests another diagnosis.

H) INCORRECT:

Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN), which is most commonly caused by systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other autoimmune conditions, often manifests with both nephritic and nephrotic syndrome. In SLE-associated DPGN, granular depositions are typically seen on immunofluorescence (staining positive for IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, C4, and C1q, the “full-house” pattern). SLE can manifest with a facial rash, and, in the case of renal involvement, gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) and facial edema. However, this patient lacks other typical symptoms of SLE (e.g., fever, fatigue, arthritis), making this diagnosis unlikely.

I) INCORRECT:

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is characterized by quickly deteriorating renal function and can manifest with gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) and facial edema, which are seen here. The various etiologies of RPGN are typically distinguished with immunofluorescence. Although immune complex-mediated RPGN (e.g., lupus nephritis, Henoch-Schonlein purpura) shows granular deposits on immunofluorescence, as seen in this patient's renal biopsy, further symptoms such as fatigue, decreased urine output, and flank pain would be expected in a patient with RPGN.
questions.hint: This patient's renal biopsy specimen shows diffuse granular deposition on immunofluorescence, which is characteristic of immune complex diseases.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 32-year-old man describes a 2-day history of oliguria, hematuria, and edema. He has no personal or family history of kidney problems. An upper respiratory tract infection 3 weeks ago resolved spontaneously.
On examination, his blood pressure is 168/95 mm Hg, and he has 3+ pitting pretibial edema bilaterally. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



Creatinine (mg/dL)
4.8
0.8–1.3


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
55
10–20


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm/hr)
56
0–17



Complement C3 (mg/dL)
44
86–184


Complement C4 (mg/dL)
20
20–58


Urinalysis reveals 3+ proteinuria, with 31 to 40 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2) and the presence of red-cell casts.
Testing for which one of the following markers is most likely to be diagnostic in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum immunoglobulin A levels play no role in diagnosing glomerulonephritis, even attributable to immunoglobulin A nephropathy. Furthermore, the latent period between the infection and the symptoms of nephritis is usually much shorter (just a few days), and hypocomplementemia is not a feature of this disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody levels are found in antineutrophil cytoplasmic-associated (“pauci-immune”) vasculitis, characterized by normal complement levels and the absence of immunoglobulin deposition on immunofluorescent staining of a kidney biopsy specimen.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's history, examination, and laboratory findings suggest postinfectious glomerulonephritis, which can occur 2 to 3 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis or cellulitis. Affected patients present with the classic features of nephritis: proteinuria, glomerular hematuria, edema, hypertension, and acute kidney injury. Laboratory findings include low complement C3 levels with normal or mildly depressed complement C4 levels, elevated antistreptolysin O and anti-deoxyribonuclease B (anti-DNAse B) titers, and a positive streptozyme test. The streptozyme test is the most useful because it measures five different antibodies that may be elevated with a recent streptococcal infection: antistreptolysin O, anti-DNAse B, antihyaluronidase, antistreptokinase, and antinicotinamide adenine dinucleotidase. The streptozyme test has a sensitivity of 95% after an episode of pharyngitis and 80% after cellulitis.

Key learning point: In a patient with features of postinfectious glomerulonephritis several weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis or cellulitis, serum complement levels are expected to be low.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody levels are found in antineutrophil cytoplasmic-associated (“pauci-immune”) vasculitis, characterized by normal complement levels and the absence of immunoglobulin deposition on immunofluorescent staining of a kidney biopsy specimen.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-glomerular basement membrane (GBM) antibodies are found in anti-GBM disease and Goodpasture syndrome, both of which are characterized by normal complement levels.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman reports acute onset of low-grade fever, frontal headache, and sore throat 3 days ago. The fever and headache have improved with over-the-counter analgesics, but the sore throat has persisted. She has had no rhinorrhea or cough. She has no significant medical history and no known drug allergies. Her 5-year-old daughter was recently diagnosed with streptococcal pharyngitis.
On examination, the patient has a temperature of 38.1°C, a heart rate of 90 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 120/80 mm Hg. Her posterior pharynx is erythematous, and she has a white exudate over enlarged tonsils. She has tender bilateral anterior cervical lymph nodes that are less than 1 cm in diameter. The rest of her physical examination is normal.
A rapid streptococcal antigen test, performed in the clinic, is negative.
What is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?

choices.text: No further treatment is necessary given the negative rapid streptococcal antigen test
Repeat the rapid streptococcal antigen test
Collect a bacterial throat culture; initiate antibiotic treatment if the result is positive

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT of the neck may be considered if a peritonsillar abscess is suspected, but this condition would be associated with other findings such as trismus, drooling, muffling of the voice, or uvular deviation, none of which are seen in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

RADTs have a wide range of sensitivities (70% to 90%), so when the results are negative but clinical suspicion remains high, it is reasonable to perform a back-up throat culture.

C) INCORRECT:

Obtaining an antistreptolysin O (ASO) titer in this patient is not recommended. A positive ASO titer is indicative of previous infection rather than a current infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Repeating the RADT in this patient is not recommended.

E) CORRECT:

In patients with pharyngitis, the 4-point Centor scoring system is used to estimate the risk for group A streptococcal (GAS) infection and to determine whether additional testing or treatment is indicated. One point is given for each of the following criteria: fever, tender cervical lymphadenopathy, tonsillar exudate, and absence of cough. The higher the Centor score, the greater the likelihood of GAS infection.

For patients with a Centor score >2, a rapid antigen-detection test (RADT) or throat culture is recommended. If the test is positive, treatment should be initiated to prevent serious complications of streptococcal infection, such as rheumatic fever.

This patient, who has a Centor score of 4, appropriately underwent rapid antigen-detection testing, but the results were negative. RADTs have a wide range of sensitivities (70% to 90%), so when the results are negative but clinical suspicion remains high, it is reasonable to perform a back-up throat culture. Given that this patient’s Centor score is high, and he also had an exposure to someone with streptococcal infection, the best next step is to obtain a throat culture. If the results of the culture are positive for GAS, antibiotic treatment should be initiated, preferably with penicillin (or with azithromycin if the patient has a penicillin allergy).

Empiric antibiotic treatment of pharyngitis on the basis of symptoms alone is no longer recommended by the Infectious Diseases Society of America, because it contributes to overuse of antibiotics.

Key learning point: Antibiotic therapy for group A streptococcal infection should be prescribed only after a positive rapid antigen-detection test or throat culture.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy reports dark-colored urine that he first noticed upon voiding this morning. He has had no recent trauma and no associated fever, back pain, abdominal pain, or dysuria. He is generally healthy but had a fever and sore throat 2 weeks ago and, for the past few days, has had congestion and rhinorrhea consistent with an upper respiratory infection.
He has a blood pressure of 116/78 mm Hg (95th percentile for his age and height) but otherwise normal vital signs. Physical examination reveals boggy nasal turbinates but is otherwise unremarkable.
A urine dipstick shows 3+ blood and 2+ protein. Urinalysis reveals numerous red cells, 10 to 20 white cells, and 3+ protein.
Which one of the following tests is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Antistreptolysin O titer and complement C3 level

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibody testing is used to screen for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Patients with SLE may present with nephritis but have other symptoms as well. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis is the most likely diagnosis in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Kidney biopsy could be considered in a case of significant renal insufficiency (glomerular filtration rate <30 mL/min/1.73 m2), if recent streptococcal infection cannot be confirmed by ASO titer or streptozyme, if proteinuria persists several weeks after diagnosis, or if low complement levels persist for >8 weeks. Given that most patients with postinfectious glomerulonephritis have a benign course, a kidney biopsy would be premature at this juncture.

C) CORRECT:

Urine can appear discolored for many reasons, including the presence of red cells (hematuria), byproducts of muscle breakdown (myoglobin), porphyrins, and pigments from certain foods (e.g., beets) and drugs.

When evaluating a patient for gross hematuria, the first step is to perform a urine dipstick test for blood; if this test is negative, then the cause is related to a food or medication. If it is positive, it indicates the presence of blood, free hemoglobin (such as from hemolysis), or free myoglobin and should be followed up with urinalysis to determine whether red cells are present. If no red cells are identified in the setting of a positive urine dipstick, then the cause of the dark urine is either free hemoglobin or myoglobin. These can be distinguished based on other laboratory data: if there is evidence of hemolysis by blood smear, then the cause is free hemoglobin; if the creatine kinase level is elevated, then the cause is myoglobin and rhabdomyolysis.

In this case, the patient is relatively hypertensive and has hematuria, pyuria, and proteinuria. Taken together, these findings suggest glomerulonephritis. Given that this condition developed 2 weeks after an upper respiratory infection, postinfectious glomerulonephritis is the most likely diagnosis, and an antistreptolysin O (ASO) titer is the most appropriate next step. A basic metabolic panel, complete blood count, and complement C3 and C4 levels should also be obtained. Most patients with postinfectious glomerulonephritis will have a depressed C3 complement level.

Key learning point: When a child presents with dark urine after a recent sore throat and fever, and urine microscopy suggests glomerulonephritis, the most appropriate next step is an antistreptolysin O titer or streptozyme test and complement C3 level.

D) INCORRECT:

A random urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio can be used to identify hypercalciuria. Hypercalciuria can lead to nephrolithiasis and hematuria. This patient’s symptoms are not consistent with renal colic, and this test would be low yield before the diagnosis of nephrolithiasis has been established.

E) INCORRECT:

Although immunoglobulin A (IgA) nephropathy can manifest with dark urine, the nephritis rarely causes hypertension and is typically synpharyngitic, as opposed to manifesting 2 weeks after the initial upper respiratory infection. Furthermore, IgA levels are not used to diagnose IgA nephropathy, as these levels could be high, low, or normal even in the setting of IgA nephropathy.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl is brought to the office because of generalized fatigue and dark urine for 4 days. Four weeks ago, she was treated with cephalexin for a skin infection. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) and blood pressure is 132/89 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 1+ pretibial edema bilaterally. Her serum creatinine is 1.7 mg/dL. Urine studies show:


Blood
2+


Protein
2+


RBC
12–14/hpf with dysmorphic features


RBC casts
numerous


Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis is a type III hypersensitivity reaction caused by the deposition of IgG immune complexes within the glomerular basement membrane, which leads to the activation and deposition of complement (mainly C3) and subsequent decrease in serum C3 due to consumption. This immune response results in damage to the glomeruli and manifests with nephritic syndrome, as seen in this patient. This condition is most commonly seen in children 1–3 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis or 1–6 weeks after streptococcal skin infection. Recovery of kidney function in children usually occurs spontaneously within 6–8 weeks. On light microscopy, PSGN manifests with enlarged and hypercellular glomeruli; on electron microscopy, it manifests with characteristic subepithelial immune complex humps.
Image Description:

Transmission electron micrograph (TEM) of renal tissue from a patient with non-HBV associated PIGN

A glomerular capillary containing a red blood cell (red overlay) and an epithelial foot process of a renal podocyte can be seen (green overlay). Multiple hump-shaped electron-dense deposits (arrows) are also apparent.

These subepithelial immune complex deposits may be present in PIGN.

Blue overlay: nucleus of endothelial cell

B) INCORRECT:

Reactive amyloidosis (AA-amyloidosis) is caused by the deposition of insoluble amyloid proteins in various organs, including the kidneys. Patients with renal involvement typically present with nephrotic syndrome, not with the nephritic syndrome seen here. Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by massive renal loss of protein (> 3.5 g/day) resulting in edema, hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, hypercoagulability (antithrombin III deficiency), and an increased risk of infection (loss of immunoglobulins). Reactive amyloidosis most commonly occurs secondary to chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., IBD, SLE, vasculitis) or chronic infections (e.g., tuberculosis, bronchiectasis), none of which are evident in this patient's history.

C) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy is thought to be caused by an increased number of defective circulating IgA antibodies. While patients with IgA nephropathy can present with nephritic syndrome following an infection, symptoms usually begin within 2–5 days after the infection, not after 3 weeks. In addition, IgA nephropathy is more commonly seen in the 2nd or 3rd decade of life and is most closely associated with mucosal infections (i.e., upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infections), rather than the skin infection seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Goodpasture syndrome is caused by autoantibodies against type IV collagen in the renal and pulmonary capillary basement membrane. While Goodpasture syndrome may manifest with nephritic syndrome and can be triggered by infections, it typically has both renal and pulmonary manifestations such as hemoptysis, cough, or dyspnea, which are not seen in this patient. Furthermore, it does not typically follow streptococcal disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Lupus nephritis is characterized by DNA-anti-DNA immune complex deposition in the glomeruli and can manifest as either nephrotic syndrome or nephritic syndrome. However, this patient's age and the absence of other systemic symptoms of SLE (e.g., malar rash, discoid rash, arthritis) make this unlikely.
questions.hint: The presence of dark urine, hypertension, edema, and microscopic hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs is indicative of nephritic syndrome.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl comes to the office with her mother because of a 2-day history of passing “cola-colored“ urine. During the past week, her mother noticed episodes of facial swelling. The patient had a rash on her face about 4 weeks ago. A renal biopsy after immunofluorescence shows diffuse granular deposition on immunofluorescence. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is an acute glomerular inflammation caused by the deposition of immune complexes along the glomerular basement membrane and mesangium in response to infection with nephritogenic strains of group A streptococci (GAS). PSGN classically occurs in children 1–6 weeks after infection (e.g., impetigo) and manifests with periorbital (or generalized) edema and gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine), both of which are seen in this patient. In addition, PSGN can also manifest with hypertension, azotemia, and proteinuria. Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 create a characteristic “lumpy-bumpy” appearance on immunofluorescence of a renal biopsy specimen.
Image Description:

Immunofluorescence photomicrograph of a renal biopsy specimen (very high magnification)

Subepithelial deposits of C3 are seen distributed within the capillary loops. The deposits are visible as bright green fluorescence in an irregular granular pattern.

This finding is typical of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in childhood, which can manifest with facial edema, as seen in this patient. MCD is thought to result from injury to podocytes and is typically triggered by a recent infection or immunization in an otherwise healthy child. However, the presence of gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) is inconsistent with this diagnosis. In addition, immunofluorescence of a renal biopsy specimen would show normal-appearing glomeruli rather than the granular deposition seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy is a type of glomerulonephritis caused by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in the mesangium. It is most common in children and young adults and can manifest with gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) and facial edema, which are seen in this patient. Immunofluorescence of a renal biopsy specimen typically shows granular deposition in the mesangium (mostly IgA). However, hematuria due to IgA nephropathy usually occurs concurrently with nonspecific respiratory, or less commonly, gastrointestinal or urinary tract infections. This patient instead presents in the postinfectious period, 4 weeks after having a rash, suggesting another diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), a rare glomerular disease that most commonly appears in childhood and early adulthood, often manifests with both nephritic and nephrotic syndrome. Based on immunofluorescence examination, there are two major types of MPGN. Immunoglobulin-mediated MPGN (type I), which is often secondary to hepatitis B or hepatitis C infection, typically involves granular deposition along the glomerular basement membrane and mesangium, as seen in this patient's biopsy. Immunofluorescence microscopy of complement-mediated MPGN (type II) typically shows C3 deposition in the glomerular capillary wall, but no granular pattern. Although both types of MPGN can manifest with gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) and facial edema, the patient's recent rash suggests another diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN), which is most commonly caused by systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other autoimmune conditions, often manifests with both nephritic and nephrotic syndrome. In SLE-associated DPGN, granular depositions are typically seen on immunofluorescence (staining positive for IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, C4, and C1q, the “full-house” pattern). SLE can manifest with a facial rash, and, in the case of renal involvement, gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) and facial edema. However, this patient lacks other typical symptoms of SLE (e.g., fever, fatigue, arthritis), making this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's renal biopsy specimen shows diffuse granular deposition on immunofluorescence, which is characteristic of immune complex diseases.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department by his parents due to tea-colored urine for the past 2 days. His mother reports a sore throat with fever about two weeks ago that resolved without medication. He denies flank pain or dysuria. There is no family history of kidney disease. On examination, he has mild periorbital edema. He has no rashes or joint pains (see lab results).

Blood pressure
130/80 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Urine




 Urinalysis

Hematuria with red blood cell casts and mild proteinuria (0.7 g/day)
Hematuria: Absent, Protein: Absent


Creatinine
88 μmol/L
27 - 62 μmol/L



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Minimal change disease typically presents with nephrotic syndrome, characterized by heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema. The presence of hematuria with red blood cell casts and proteinuria of 0.7 g/day indicates a glomerular process, not minimal change disease. Elevated blood pressure and creatinine are also atypical for minimal change disease.

B) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy is associated with hematuria occurring during or immediately after an upper respiratory infection, not with a two-week delay. The absence of active infection at the time of renal symptoms and the presence of periorbital edema and elevated creatinine suggest a different immune complex-mediated reaction.

C) CORRECT:

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is an immune complex-mediated glomerular injury occurring 1–3 weeks after a streptococcal infection, such as a sore throat. The tea-colored urine indicates hematuria, and red blood cell casts localize the bleeding to the glomerulus. Mild proteinuria reflects compromised glomerular filtration. Periorbital edema and elevated blood pressure suggest fluid retention due to reduced glomerular filtration rate. Immunologically, antigen-antibody complexes deposit in the glomerular basement membrane, activating complement pathways and causing inflammation. These clinical and laboratory findings align with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

Key learning point: Coca cola-coloured urine, hematuria, recent upper respiratory infection, and hypertension in a child suggest post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, a type of acute glomerulonephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Membranous nephropathy usually occurs in adults and presents with nephrotic range proteinuria, not mild proteinuria. The presence of red blood cell casts indicates a nephritic process, aligning more with post-infectious glomerulonephritis. The recent sore throat suggests an immunological response, not typical for membranous nephropathy.

questions.text:

Complement C3

0.7 - 1.5 g/L


Complement C4
0.3 g/L
0.15 - 0.45 g/L



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Minimal change disease is characterized by nephrotic-range proteinuria, minimal hematuria, and normal complement levels. The presence of red blood cell casts and low C3 levels suggests immune-mediated glomerular injury, which is inconsistent with minimal change disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) can present with low C3 levels, but it usually manifests as a chronic condition. It is not typically preceded by streptococcal pharyngitis. The acute onset and age of the patient are more indicative of an acute post-infectious process rather than MPGN.

C) CORRECT:

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis manifests with hematuria, mild edema, and hypertension following a streptococcal infection. The presence of red blood cell casts indicates glomerular inflammation, while sub-nephrotic range proteinuria suggests a nephritic process. Reduced serum complement C3 with normal C4 levels reflects activation of the alternative complement pathway by immune complexes in the glomeruli. The clinical timeline and laboratory findings, including elevated blood pressure, align with the immunopathogenesis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

Key learning point: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is characterized by hematuria, hypertension, edema, and low complement C3 levels following a streptococcal infection.

D) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy is associated with hematuria concurrent with or immediately after an upper respiratory infection, not weeks later. It typically does not cause decreased complement levels, as IgA deposition does not significantly consume complement. The low C3 level and timing of symptoms do not support IgA nephropathy.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presents with swelling around his eyes for the past two days, reduced urine output, and tea-colored urine. Two weeks ago, he had a sore throat with fever that resolved spontaneously. He now reports fatigue and mild flank discomfort. He has no significant medical history and is not on any medications. Examination shows periorbital and mild pedal edema (see lab results).

Blood pressure
130/85 mmHg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Creatinine
120 μmol/L
27 - 62 μmol/L


Urine




 Urinalysis

Red blood cells, RBC casts, mild proteinuria

No RBCs, no casts, no proteinuria



Which diagnosis best explains this patient’s findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis manifests following a streptococcal infection, such as pharyngitis, with a latency period of approximately two weeks. Immune complex deposition in the glomeruli triggers complement activation and inflammation, leading to reduced glomerular filtration. Clinical features include periorbital and pedal edema, tea-colored urine, and elevated serum creatinine, indicating impaired kidney function. Urinalysis reveals red blood cells and red blood cell casts, reflecting glomerular inflammation. This condition is common in children and typically follows a recent streptococcal infection, aligning with the patient's history and laboratory findings.

Key learning point: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis typically presents 1-3 weeks after a streptococcal infection with hematuria, proteinuria, edema, and hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Minimal change disease is characterized by nephrotic syndrome with massive proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema, without significant hematuria or red blood cell casts. The presence of tea-colored urine, hematuria, and elevated creatinine suggests an inflammatory glomerular process, not typical of minimal change disease.

C) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy typically presents with hematuria concurrent with a mucosal infection, such as an upper respiratory tract infection. This synpharyngitic pattern contrasts with the post-infectious timing seen here. Additionally, IgA nephropathy usually presents with less pronounced renal dysfunction and systemic signs like edema.

D) INCORRECT:

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) often presents with a more insidious onset and is associated with chronic infections or systemic conditions. The acute onset following a recent infection and the clinical context suggest an acute post-infectious process rather than the chronic course typical of MPGN.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of facial swelling and dark-colored urine. He reports recovering from a severe sore throat about three weeks earlier. He denies other significant past medical issues or medication use. Physical examination reveals periorbital edema and mild pitting edema in both ankles (see lab results and report).

Blood pressure
150/90 mm Hg

Red blood cell casts present; Protein: 1 g/day

Creatinine
180 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Complement C3
0.5 g/L
0.7 - 1.5 g/L



Chest X-ray: Unremarkable
Which diagnosis best explains this presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute interstitial nephritis often results from drug exposure and presents with fever, rash, and eosinophilia. It does not typically involve red blood cell casts or decreased complement levels, which suggest a glomerular process. The history of a recent sore throat and the laboratory findings support a post-infectious glomerulonephritis rather than interstitial nephritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Membranous nephropathy is associated with nephrotic syndrome, significant proteinuria, and normal complement levels. It rarely presents with red blood cell casts. The moderate proteinuria, hematuria with red blood cell casts, low C3 levels, and recent infection history suggest an immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis, not membranous nephropathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Minimal change disease typically presents with nephrotic syndrome, characterized by heavy proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, and edema. It usually maintains normal renal function and complement levels, and lacks red blood cell casts. The presence of red blood cell casts, elevated creatinine, and low C3 levels indicate an inflammatory glomerular process, not minimal change disease.

D) CORRECT:

Acute poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis manifests after streptococcal infections, such as pharyngitis, due to immune complex deposition in the glomeruli. This leads to complement activation, resulting in decreased serum complement C3 levels. Clinical features include periorbital edema, dark urine with red blood cell casts, and mild proteinuria, indicating glomerular injury. Hypertension and elevated serum creatinine suggest impaired renal function due to glomerular inflammation. The temporal relationship with a recent streptococcal infection and the laboratory findings align with this diagnosis.

Key learning point: Acute glomerulonephritis can present with edema, hematuria, and renal impairment, and should be considered in patients with unexplained edema and fatigue.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy presents with puffy eyelids and cola-colored urine for the past two days to the clinic. He had a sore throat about three weeks ago. He has no significant past medical history and denies any recent medications. Vital signs show mild hypertension (see lab results).

Blood pressure
130/85 mm Hg

0.5 g/L
0.7 - 1.5 g/L


Complement C4
0.3 g/L
0.15 - 0.45 g/L



Which of the following best explains the decreased serum C3 level in this condition?

choices.text: IgA-mediated alternative pathway activation typical of Berger disease
Abnormal complement regulation due to a hereditary defect in factor H
Autoantibody-mediated complement activation consistent with lupus nephritis
Complement consumption by immune complexes associated with recent infection

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy involves mesangial deposition of IgA immune complexes, which does not typically cause significant serum C3 decrease. The history of sore throat, cola-colored urine, and low C3 with normal C4 aligns with post-infectious glomerulonephritis, not IgA nephropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Hereditary defects in factor H lead to dysregulation of the alternative complement pathway, causing persistent low C3 levels. However, the acute presentation following streptococcal pharyngitis, with puffy eyelids and cola-colored urine, is characteristic of post-infectious glomerulonephritis, not a genetic complement regulatory disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

In lupus nephritis, immune complexes formed by autoantibodies activate the classical complement pathway, leading to decreased levels of both C3 and C4. The clinical information here, including a recent sore throat, RBC casts, and isolated C3 decrease with normal C4, aligns with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, not lupus nephritis.

D) CORRECT:

In post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, immune complexes form in response to a prior group A streptococcal infection and deposit in the glomeruli. This deposition activates the complement cascade, primarily via the classical pathway, leading to the consumption of complement proteins, notably C3. The reduction in serum C3 levels reflects this consumption and is a key laboratory finding in this condition. The hypocomplementemia is typically transient, with levels returning to normal as the immune complexes are cleared.

Key learning point: In post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, low complement C3 levels are a key diagnostic finding due to complement consumption in the immune complex-mediated process.

A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to cola-colored urine and facial puffiness for two days. He had a sore throat that resolved spontaneously two weeks ago. Physical examination shows periorbital edema, mild ankle swelling, and no rash (see lab results and report).

Blood pressure

Renal biopsy: Pending result
Which electron microscopy finding is most characteristic of this condition?

choices.text: Linear immunoglobulin G deposition along the glomerular basement membrane
Mesangial immunoglobulin A immune complex deposits
Subendothelial immune complex deposits with a tram-track appearance

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Linear IgG deposition along the glomerular basement membrane is characteristic of anti-glomerular basement membrane disease, such as Goodpasture's syndrome. This pattern results from direct autoantibody binding and appears as a continuous line on immunofluorescence, unlike the granular immune complex deposits seen in post-infectious glomerulonephritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Mesangial IgA deposits are indicative of IgA nephropathy, which presents with hematuria concurrent with mucosal infections and normal complement levels. The clinical presentation of post-infectious glomerulonephritis, with decreased serum C3 and a history of streptococcal infection, is inconsistent with IgA nephropathy.

C) CORRECT:

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is characterized by the deposition of immune complexes formed between streptococcal antigens and host antibodies in the subepithelial space of the glomerular basement membrane. Electron microscopy reveals these as dome-shaped, electron-dense deposits. This immune-mediated injury activates the complement cascade, leading to decreased serum C3 levels. The presence of subepithelial humps is a hallmark of the disease, correlating with clinical features such as hematuria and edema following a recent streptococcal infection.

Key learning point: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is characterized by hematuria and hypertension following a streptococcal infection, typically occurring 1-3 weeks after the infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Subendothelial immune complex deposits with a tram-track appearance are associated with membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. This condition involves splitting of the glomerular basement membrane. In post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, electron microscopy typically shows subepithelial hump-shaped deposits, not subendothelial deposits.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy presents to the clinic with dark, reddish-brown urine and mild facial swelling for two days. His mother reports a sore throat approximately two weeks ago that resolved without medication. He is afebrile. Examination is otherwise normal. Urinalysis shows red blood cell casts and mild proteinuria. Serum complement C3 is reduced. Additional labs reveal normal serum albumin and normal renal function. He denies joint pain or skin lesions. Vital signs are otherwise stable.

Blood pressure
130/85 mm Hg

Which of the following laboratory tests is most appropriate to confirm a recent streptococcal infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum rheumatoid factor is used to assess autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, not recent streptococcal infections. The patient's presentation, including hematuria and reduced complement C3 after a sore throat, suggests post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, which is not associated with rheumatoid factor.

B) CORRECT:

Serum antistreptolysin O (ASO) titer measures antibodies against streptolysin O, a toxin produced by group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus. This test is useful for confirming recent streptococcal infection, particularly in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). The patient's symptoms, including hematuria with red blood cell casts, mild proteinuria, and reduced serum complement C3 following pharyngitis, suggest PSGN. ASO titers typically rise 1 to 3 weeks after infection, aligning with the timeline of this patient's presentation.

Key learning point: In a child presenting with tea-colored urine, hypertension, and recent pharyngitis, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis should be suspected, and an anti-streptolysin O titer is the appropriate investigation to confirm recent streptococcal infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Serum anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies are primarily used to evaluate systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), not streptococcal infections. While both SLE and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis can present with reduced complement C3, the patient's recent sore throat and isolated renal findings suggest PSGN, not SLE.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies are used to diagnose Goodpasture’s syndrome, characterized by rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage. The patient's symptoms and reduced complement C3 suggest an immune complex–mediated process like post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, not anti-GBM disease.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with two days of periorbital swelling and dark tea-colored urine. He recently recovered from a skin infection with honey-colored crusted lesions on his face. Examination shows periorbital edema and mild rales on lung auscultation (see lab results).

Blood pressure
135/85 mmHg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Urine




 Urinalysis
Red blood cell casts: Present
Red blood cell casts: Absent


Creatinine
80 μmol/L
27 - 62 μmol/L



Which additional laboratory finding is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Elevated anti-glomerular basement membrane antibody titer

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies are associated with Goodpasture syndrome, characterized by pulmonary hemorrhage and renal involvement. This patient’s mild rales and recent streptococcal skin infection suggest a post-infectious glomerulonephritis rather than an autoimmune process like Goodpasture syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum immunoglobulin A is associated with IgA nephropathy, which presents with hematuria following mucosal infections. However, the recent streptococcal skin infection, periorbital edema, and red blood cell casts suggest poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, characterized by decreased complement levels, not elevated IgA.

C) INCORRECT:

Reduced serum albumin is typical of nephrotic syndrome, characterized by heavy proteinuria. This patient’s presentation, including hematuria, hypertension, and elevated creatinine, is consistent with nephritic syndrome, such as postinfectious glomerulonephritis, where proteinuria is not severe enough to cause hypoalbuminemia.

D) CORRECT:

The presentation of periorbital edema, dark tea-colored urine, and hypertension following a streptococcal skin infection is indicative of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. This condition involves immune complex deposition in the glomeruli, activating the complement system via the alternative pathway. This activation leads to consumption of complement components, notably C₃, resulting in decreased serum C₃ levels. The presence of red blood cell casts in the urine further supports glomerular inflammation and damage, aligning with the diagnosis of acute glomerulonephritis in children post-streptococcal infection.

Key learning point: Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis often follows a streptococcal infection such as impetigo or pharyngitis, and presents with edema, hematuria, hypertension, and renal impairment.

questions.text:
You are seeing a 7-year-old girl who is brought to your clinic with a 1-week history of generalized fatigue and dark urine. Four weeks ago, she was treated with topical mupirocin for a skin infection. Her medical history is unremarkable, and she does not take any routine medications. Her 5-year-old brother has steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome. Her temperature is 37°C, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 132/89 mm Hg. On examination, she has periorbital and 1+ pretibial edema bilaterally. The remainder of the examination is normal. Laboratory studies show:

129 g/L (115–155)

7.2 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)

2+

2+

Negative

12–14/hpf with dysmorphic features

Numerous


Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

choices.text: Abnormal deposits of insoluble protein fibers.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Goodpasture syndrome is caused by autoantibodies against type IV collagen in the renal and pulmonary capillary basement membrane. While Goodpasture syndrome may manifest with nephritis and can be triggered by infections, it often causes both renal and pulmonary manifestations such as hemoptysis, cough, or dyspnea, which are not seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is caused by antinuclear antibodies and anti-dsDNA autoantibodies. Lupus nephritis is common in patients with SLE and is classically an immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis. While patients with lupus nephritis also present with nephritic syndrome, this patient lacks other systemic symptoms of SLE such as lesions of the skin (e.g., malar rash, discoid rash, oral ulcers), arthritis, and fever.

C) INCORRECT:

Reactive amyloidosis (AA-amyloidosis) is caused by the deposition of amyloid-associated protein in various organs, including the kidneys. Patients with renal involvement present with nephrotic syndrome, not with nephritic syndrome as seen in this patient. Patients may also present with type II renal tubular acidosis or nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Reactive amyloidosis occurs secondarily to chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., inflammatory bowel disease, systemic lupus erythematosus, vasculitis) or chronic infections (e.g., tuberculosis, bronchiectasis), none of which are evident in this patient's history.

D) CORRECT:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis is caused by the deposition of immune complexes composed of IgG and C3 complement that contain the streptococcal antigen within the glomerular basement membrane. The deposition of immune complexes activates complement, additional immune mediators, and leads to local inflammation. This immune response damages the glomeruli and results in nephritic syndrome. Laboratory tests commonly also show decreased C3 complement levels due to activation of the alternative complement pathway.

The condition is typically self-limiting; treatment is supportive and focuses on complications of volume overload. Recovery of kidney function usually occurs within 6–8 weeks. While 90% of pediatric cases recover completely, approximately 50% of adult patients retain persistently reduced renal function.

Key learning point: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis is a nephritic syndrome caused by subepithelial immune complex deposition that activates complement and leads to glomerular inflammation.
Image Description:

Immunofluorescence photomicrograph of a renal biopsy specimen (very high magnification)

Subepithelial deposits of C3 are seen distributed within the capillary loops. The deposits are visible as bright green fluorescence in an irregular granular pattern.

This finding is typical of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.

E) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy is thought to be caused by an increased number of defective circulating IgA antibodies. While patients with IgA nephropathy may present with nephritic syndrome following an infection, symptoms usually begin within 2–5 days after the infection, not after 3 weeks. In addition, IgA nephropathy is more commonly seen in the 2nd or 3rd decade of life and is most closely associated with mucosal infections (i.e., upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infections).
questions.hint: The presence of dark urine, hypertension, edema, and microscopic hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs is indicative of nephritic syndrome. This condition can occur within 3–4 weeks after infections with group A streptococci such as impetigo.
