questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lupus nephritis is characterized by DNA-anti-DNA immune complex deposition in the glomeruli and can manifest as either nephrotic syndrome or nephritic syndrome. However, this patient's age and the absence of other systemic symptoms of SLE (e.g., malar rash, discoid rash, arthritis) make this unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Reactive amyloidosis (AA-amyloidosis) is caused by the deposition of insoluble amyloid proteins in various organs, including the kidneys. Patients with renal involvement typically present with nephrotic syndrome, not with the nephritic syndrome seen here. Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by massive renal loss of protein (> 3.5 g/day) resulting in edema, hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, hypercoagulability (antithrombin III deficiency), and an increased risk of infection (loss of immunoglobulins). Reactive amyloidosis most commonly occurs secondary to chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., IBD, SLE, vasculitis) or chronic infections (e.g., tuberculosis, bronchiectasis), none of which are evident in this patient's history.

C) INCORRECT:

Goodpasture syndrome is caused by autoantibodies against type IV collagen in the renal and pulmonary capillary basement membrane. While Goodpasture syndrome may manifest with nephritic syndrome and can be triggered by infections, it typically has both renal and pulmonary manifestations such as hemoptysis, cough, or dyspnea, which are not seen in this patient. Furthermore, it does not typically follow streptococcal disease.

D) CORRECT:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis is a type III hypersensitivity reaction caused by the deposition of IgG immune complexes within the glomerular basement membrane, which leads to the activation and deposition of complement (mainly C3) and subsequent decrease in serum C3 due to consumption. This immune response results in damage to the glomeruli and manifests with nephritic syndrome, as seen in this patient. This condition is most commonly seen in children 1–3 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis or 1–6 weeks after streptococcal skin infection. Recovery of kidney function in children usually occurs spontaneously within 6–8 weeks. On light microscopy, PSGN manifests with enlarged and hypercellular glomeruli; on electron microscopy, it manifests with characteristic subepithelial immune complex humps.

Key learning point: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis is a classic cause of nephritic syndrome in children, typically occurring 1–6 weeks after a streptococcal skin or throat infection.
Image Description:

Transmission electron micrograph (TEM) of renal tissue from a patient with non-HBV associated PIGN

A glomerular capillary containing a red blood cell (red overlay) and an epithelial foot process of a renal podocyte can be seen (green overlay). Multiple hump-shaped electron-dense deposits (arrows) are also apparent.

These subepithelial immune complex deposits may be present in PIGN.

Blue overlay: nucleus of endothelial cell

E) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy is thought to be caused by an increased number of defective circulating IgA antibodies. While patients with IgA nephropathy can present with nephritic syndrome following an infection, symptoms usually begin within 2–5 days after the infection, not after 3 weeks. In addition, IgA nephropathy is more commonly seen in the 2nd or 3rd decade of life and is most closely associated with mucosal infections (i.e., upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infections), rather than the skin infection seen in this patient.
questions.hint: The presence of dark urine, hypertension, edema, and microscopic hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs is indicative of nephritic syndrome.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl is brought to your clinic by her mother because of a 2-day history of passing “cola-colored” urine. Over the past week, her mother has noticed episodes of facial swelling. The patient had a facial rash about 4 weeks ago. Renal biopsy with immunofluorescence shows diffuse granular deposition. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy is a type of glomerulonephritis caused by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in the mesangium. It is most common in children and young adults and can manifest with gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) and facial edema, which are seen in this patient. Immunofluorescence of a renal biopsy specimen typically shows granular deposition in the mesangium (mostly IgA). However, hematuria due to IgA nephropathy usually occurs concurrently with nonspecific respiratory, or less commonly, gastrointestinal or urinary tract infections. This patient instead presents in the postinfectious period, 4 weeks after having a rash, suggesting another diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in childhood, which can manifest with facial edema, as seen in this patient. MCD is thought to result from injury to podocytes and is typically triggered by a recent infection or immunization in an otherwise healthy child. However, the presence of gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) is inconsistent with this diagnosis. In addition, immunofluorescence of a renal biopsy specimen would show normal-appearing glomeruli rather than the granular deposition seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN), which is most commonly caused by systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other autoimmune conditions, often manifests with both nephritic and nephrotic syndrome. In SLE-associated DPGN, granular depositions are typically seen on immunofluorescence (staining positive for IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, C4, and C1q, the “full-house” pattern). SLE can manifest with a facial rash, and, in the case of renal involvement, gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) and facial edema. However, this patient lacks other typical symptoms of SLE (e.g., fever, fatigue, arthritis), making this diagnosis unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is an acute glomerular inflammation caused by the deposition of immune complexes along the glomerular basement membrane and mesangium in response to infection with nephritogenic strains of group A streptococci (GAS). PSGN classically occurs in children 1–6 weeks after infection (e.g., impetigo) and manifests with periorbital (or generalized) edema and gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine), both of which are seen in this patient. In addition, PSGN can also manifest with hypertension, azotemia, and proteinuria. Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 create a characteristic “lumpy-bumpy” appearance on immunofluorescence of a renal biopsy specimen.

Key learning point: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis typically presents 1–6 weeks after streptococcal infection with hematuria, edema, and granular immune complex deposition on renal biopsy.
Image Description:

Immunofluorescence photomicrograph of a renal biopsy specimen (very high magnification)

Subepithelial deposits of C3 are seen distributed within the capillary loops. The deposits are visible as bright green fluorescence in an irregular granular pattern.

This finding is typical of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), a rare glomerular disease that most commonly appears in childhood and early adulthood, often manifests with both nephritic and nephrotic syndrome. Based on immunofluorescence examination, there are two major types of MPGN. Immunoglobulin-mediated MPGN (type I), which is often secondary to hepatitis B or hepatitis C infection, typically involves granular deposition along the glomerular basement membrane and mesangium, as seen in this patient's biopsy. Immunofluorescence microscopy of complement-mediated MPGN (type II) typically shows C3 deposition in the glomerular capillary wall, but no granular pattern. Although both types of MPGN can manifest with gross hematuria (“cola-colored” urine) and facial edema, the patient's recent rash suggests another diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient's renal biopsy specimen shows diffuse granular deposition on immunofluorescence, which is characteristic of immune complex diseases.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with her mother, who reports that the child has had very dark urine in her diapers for the past 2 days. The patient has no significant past medical history except she was treated with topical mupirocin for impetigo 3 weeks ago. On examination, she has with prominent periorbital edema and blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg. Urinalysis reveals hematuria with red blood cell casts and mild proteinuria. What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic study to support the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ANCA testing is used to evaluate for ANCA-associated vasculitis, which can cause rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis but typically presents with more severe renal dysfunction and systemic symptoms. The preceeding impetigo and clinical features make another diagnosis more likely than ANCA-associated disease in this pediatric patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-GBM antibodies are associated with Goodpasture syndrome, which typically presents with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary-renal syndrome. This condition is rare in children and the clinical presentation lacks the pulmonary involvement that would suggest anti-GBM disease.

C) INCORRECT:

While drug-induced hemolytic anemia can cause dark urine and acute kidney injury, this typically occurs after exposure to systemic medications and is rare with topical medications. Additional evidence of hemolysis, such as signs of anemia and jaundice, would also typically be present. The clinical presentation of hypertension, periorbital edema, and nephritic urinalysis suggests an alternative diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – Elevated ASO antibody titers provide evidence of recent streptococcal infection, which is essential for diagnosing poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. This patient's presentation of nephritic syndrome with dark urine, hypertension, periorbital edema, and nephritic urinalysis occurring 3 weeks after a soft tissue infection is classic for PSGN. Anti-DNase B antibodies may also be elevated and provide additional confirmation of preceding group A streptococcal infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound and biopsy is not routinely performed for suspected PSGN. Ultrasound findings are usually normal or have nonspecific changes. Biopsy is reserved for cases with atypical presentation, signs of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, or persistently low complement levels beyond 12 weeks.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of dark, cola-colored urine and swelling around his eyes and ankles. He reports having a severe sore throat and fever 2 weeks ago, which resolved without treatment. His blood pressure is 152/94 mm Hg. Physical examination shows periorbital and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Urinalysis shows large blood and 2+ protein. Microscopic examination of the urine sediment shows numerous red blood cells and red blood cell casts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pyelonephritis is an infection of the kidney parenchyma and renal pelvis. While it can cause hematuria, the classic presentation includes fever, flank pain, and costovertebral angle tenderness. The urinalysis would typically show pyuria, bacteriuria, and WBC casts. This patient's presentation of hypertension, edema, and RBC casts is not consistent with pyelonephritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Urolithiasis (i.e., kidney stones) commonly presents with acute, severe flank pain and gross hematuria. However, it does not cause the hypertension, significant edema, or proteinuria seen in this patient. Furthermore, urine microscopy would show RBCs but would not show RBC casts, as the bleeding originates from the urothelial lining, not the glomeruli.

C) INCORRECT:

Bladder cancer typically presents with painless gross hematuria, primarily in older adults with a history of smoking. It does not cause the acute onset of hypertension, edema, or proteinuria. The presence of RBC casts effectively rules out a lower urinary tract source of bleeding, such as a bladder tumor.

D) CORRECT:

This patient presents with the classic nephritic syndrome triad of hematuria, hypertension, and edema. The history of a sore throat 2 weeks prior suggests post-streptococcal disease, a common cause of acute glomerulonephritis. The dark, cola-colored urine indicates glomerular bleeding, in which blood is altered as it passes through the nephron. The most specific finding confirming glomerular inflammation and injury is the presence of RBC casts on urine microscopy. These casts are formed when RBCs become trapped within the proteinaceous matrix of the renal tubules, indicating an intrarenal, specifically glomerular, source of bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) can cause acute kidney injury and hematuria. However, AIN is typically associated with a drug reaction and often manifests with fever, rash, and eosinophilia. The urinalysis in AIN characteristically shows WBC casts and eosinophiluria, not the RBC casts seen in this patient. Significant hypertension and edema are also less common in AIN.
questions.hint: The presence of red blood cell (RBC) casts on urine microscopy is a pathognomonic finding for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with dark urine and facial edema two weeks after a streptococcal infection. Which laboratory finding is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum immunoglobulin A is associated with IgA nephropathy, not acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. IgA nephropathy typically presents with hematuria concurrent with an upper respiratory infection, unlike the delayed presentation seen in PSGN.

B) INCORRECT:

Low serum C₄ is not typical in acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, which primarily involves the alternative complement pathway, leading to low C₃ levels. Low C₄ is more characteristic of conditions involving the classical complement pathway, such as systemic lupus erythematosus.

C) CORRECT:

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) manifests with dark urine and facial edema following a streptococcal infection. It is an immune complex-mediated glomerular injury that activates the alternative complement pathway, leading to consumption of complement component C₃. This results in low serum C₃ levels, while C₄ levels remain normal. The reduction in C₃ is a key diagnostic indicator of PSGN, reflecting the underlying pathophysiology of immune complex deposition and complement activation.

Key learning point: Low C3 complement levels are a key laboratory finding in acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, indicating complement consumption in the immune complex-mediated process.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies are specific for systemic lupus erythematosus, not post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. PSGN is characterized by low serum C₃ due to immune complex deposition and complement activation, without the presence of anti-dsDNA antibodies.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of swelling around his eyes for the past 2 days. His mother also notes that his urine became gradually darker during this time. Three weeks ago, he was treated for bacterial tonsillitis. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 79/min, and blood pressure is 158/87 mm Hg. Examination shows periorbital swelling. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



Urea nitrogen
9 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.7 mg/dL


Urine



Protein
2+


RBC
12/hpf


RBC casts
numerous


A renal biopsy would most likely show which of the following findings?

choices.text: "Spike-and-dome" appearance of subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy
Splitting and alternating thickening and thinning of the glomerular basement membrane on light microscopy
Effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy
Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 on immunofluorescence
Glomerular crescent moon formation on light microscopy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A “spike-and-dome” appearance of subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy is a typical finding of membranous nephropathy (MN). This condition usually manifests with nephrotic syndrome, as opposed to the nephritic syndrome seen in this patient. MN rarely manifests in childhood; however, when children are affected, the most common associations include hepatitis B infection and autoimmune or thyroid disease, none of which is present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Splitting and alternating thickening and thinning of the glomerular basement membrane on light microscopy may be seen in both Alport syndrome and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). These conditions typically manifest with nephritic syndrome, which is seen in this patient. However, other characteristic features of Alport syndrome include visual disturbances and sensorineural hearing loss, neither of which this patient has. MPGN can either be secondary to infection (e.g., hepatitis C) or autoimmune disease, of which there is no evidence in this patient, or idiopathic. This patient's recent history of bacterial tonsillitis suggests a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Mesangial IgA-based immune complex deposits on immunofluorescence are a typical finding of IgA nephropathy. This type of glomerulonephritis may manifest with nephritic syndrome, which is seen in this patient. However, IgA nephropathy most commonly occurs during or immediately following (2–5 days) an upper respiratory/gastrointestinal tract infection and not 2–4 weeks after. Also, IgA nephropathy is not typically associated with bacterial tonsillitis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain)

A glomerulus surrounded by numerous tubules is visible in the center of each image. There is a proliferation of mesangial cells (examples marked by yellow circles) with extracellular matrix deposition within the glomeruli. In IgA nephropathy, these changes can range from focal segmental (examples indicated by black arrows) to diffuse (examples indicated by yellow arrow-heads).

This is the characteristic histopathologic appearance of IgA nephropathy.

Blue outlines: Glomerular capillaries

D) INCORRECT:

Effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy is a typical finding of minimal change disease (MCD). MCD is most commonly seen in children. However, it manifests with nephrotic syndrome, as opposed to the nephritic syndrome seen in this patient. MCD is mainly idiopathic but may be triggered by recent infections or develop secondary to lymphoma.
Image Description:

Electron micrograph of kidney tissue

The effacement of the podocytes foot processes is visible (examples indicated by green outline) as well as swelling of podocyte bodies (example indicated by red overlay).

This finding, together with unremarkable light microscopy, is typical of minimal change disease.

E) CORRECT:

Typical renal biopsy findings of PSGN include granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 along the glomerular basement membrane and mesangium on immunofluorescence (“lumpy-bumpy” or “starry sky” appearance), enlarged and hypercellular glomeruli on light microscopy, and subepithelial immune complex deposits (“humps”) on electron microscopy. In response to infection with nephritogenic strains of group A streptococci (e.g., bacterial tonsillitis), immune complexes containing the streptococcal antigen deposit in the subendothelial and subepithelial space. These immune complexes trigger an immune response (via complement activation) that destroys glomeruli. The subendothelial deposits are rapidly cleared by circulating immune cells and may not be present on renal biopsy unless performed in the early stages of PSGN.
Image Description:

Fluorescence microscopy (immunofluorescence staining for C3; high magnification)

Granular deposits of C3 are visible, resulting in a starry sky pattern.

F) INCORRECT:

Glomerular crescent moon formation on light microscopy is seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). RPGN is characterized by the rapid destruction of renal glomeruli manifesting as nephritic syndrome, which is seen here. Although poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) can progress to RPGN, normal blood urea nitrogen, relatively mild creatinine elevation, and no changes in urinary output after 2 days of PSGN make RPGN unlikely in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney biopsy tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

A hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone with an inflammatory infiltrate (yellow overlay) is visible within the glomerulus.

Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs and symptoms of nephritic syndrome (periorbital edema, gross hematuria with RBC casts, mild proteinuria, elevated creatinine, and hypertension) 3 weeks after an episode of bacterial tonsillitis. This presentation should raise suspicion for poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).
